Regulating the MnOx structure in Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst to enhance the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen in liquid phase Jianhang Zhang Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Qianqian Shi Methodology Investigation Data curation Peizheng Zhao Methodology Data curation Qinghu Tang Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization ⁎ Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang, Henan 453007, PR China Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University Xinxiang Henan 453007 PR China Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang, Henan 453007, PR China ⁎ Correspondence to: 46 Jianshe East Road, Xinxiang, Henan 453007, PR China 46 Jianshe East Road Xinxiang Henan 453007 PR China Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by a facile sequential precipitation- deposition method were investigated for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalyst were characterized by multiple analytical and characterization techniques. It was found that the highly dispersed MnO(OH) could significantly improve the catalyst activity. When a Mn loading of ca. 10 wt% was used, the catalytic activity of supported Ru catalyst was the highest. The benzyl alcohol conversion and the selectivity of benzaldehyde after 1 h reaction at 80 °C were 100 % and 99 %, respectively. Excessive Mn, however, would lead to large amount of aggregated Mn3O4, resulting in a poor activity. The Mn in the sample roasted below 300 °C was highly dispersed MnO(OH), and the corresponding catalyst showed a high activity. High-temperature aggregated MnO(OH) to Mn3O4, leading to a decreased catalyst activity. Graphical abstract Keywords Aerobic oxidation Benzyl alcohol MnO(OH) Molecular oxygen Ruthenium catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aerobic oxidation alcohol to the corresponding carbonyl compound is one of the important reactions in organic synthesis, which has been widely used in the synthesis of fine chemicals and organic intermediates [1–5]. Traditionally, the oxidation of alcohol is carried out in a stoichiometric manner by using Cr(VI), Mn(VII) or other inorganic strong oxidants [6,7], and the process has been shown to produce large amounts of pollutants. From the viewpoint of environmental friendliness and sustainable chemistry, it is of great scientific significance to develop a greener method to oxidize alcohol by using solid catalyst and molecule oxygen as the sole oxidant. Transition metal catalysts are considered to be the most attractive research direction due to the high atomic efficiency [1]. Most of catalysts for aerobic oxidation of alcohol using oxygen or air as the oxidant reported in literature are focused on Ru [8–12], Pt [13,14], Pd [15–18] and Au [19], and there are also some reports involving in Cu [20,21], Fe [22,23], Ni [24,25], V [26,27], Mn [28–31] and other transition metals. Among them, heterogeneous Ru catalyst has attracted extensive attentions due to its relative cheapness, high efficiency and high selectivity to carbonyl compound [32]. In past years, RuO2 [33], Ru/Al2O3 [34], Ru/hydrotalcite [35], Ru/CeO2 [36], and Ru/Co/hydroxyapatite [37] have been reported to be efficient for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol, acrylate alcohol and adipose alcohol, but their catalytic activities are still not ideal from the perspective of technical application. Kockritz and co-workers [38,39] reported that doping other transition metal such as Fe, Cu, Mn or/and Co could effectively improve the catalytic activity of Ru heterogeneous catalyst. Among them, the multi-center Ru-Mn catalyst synthesized by doping Mn showed the best catalytic activity, and the synergistic effect between Ru and Mn was considered to be the key to enhance the catalytic activity. Due to the complex structure of doped Mn, the nature of the synergistic effect between Ru and Mn is still unknown. In this communication, a series of Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a facile sequential precipitation-deposition method and their catalytic performances for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant were investigated. In order to establish the relationship between catalytic structure and performance, the synthesized catalysts were characterized by multiple analytical and characterization techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physisorption, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction ( H2-TPR), etc. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals purchased from Sinopharm Group Co., Ltd. were analytical grade, and no further treatment was done before use. MnO, Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO2 obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd were used as the reference compounds. MnO(OH) prepared from KMnO4 and CH3CH2OH by using a solvothermal method reported by Zhang et al. [40] was also used as a reference compound. Fig. S1 showed the XRD pattern of the prepared MnO(OH), which was consistent with that reported in reference [40]. All the peaks in the pattern could be indexed to monoclinic MnO(OH) (JCPDS 99–0075). The γ-Al2O3 carrier with a surface area of 195 m2/g was obtained by roasting commercial aluminum hydroxide (from Fuchen (Tianjin) Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd) at 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by a sequential precipitation-deposition method, as shown in Fig. 1. Firstly, 2.0 g of roasted γ-Al2O3 was immersed to a Mn(NO3)2 aqueous solution (100 mL) for 1 h, and then a NaOH solution (0.1 mol/L) was dropwise added to the mixture at room temperature under continuous agitation until a pH of 9.0. The resulting slurry was aged at room temperature for 24 h, then filtered and washed with deionized water until a neutral pH. After drying at 110 °C for 3 h, the resulting solid was roasted at a designed temperature in air for 3 h. The obtained solid sample was named as yMnOx/γ-Al2O3-z, where y and z represented the theoretical weight percentage of Mn and the roasting temperature, respectively. The Ru/yMnOx/γ-Al2O3-z catalyst was obtained by a modified procedure for the preparation of Ru/Al2O3 [34]. Typically, 2.0 g of yMnOx/γ-Al2O3-z was immersed to an aqueous solution of RuCl3 (100 mL). After vigorously stirring at room temperature for 1 h, a NaOH solution (1 mol/L) was dropwise added to the mixture under continuous agitation until a pH of 13.0. The resulting slurry was further stirred for 4 h, then filtered and washed with deionized water until a neutral pH. The final solid was dried at 80 °C for 6 h to obtain the Ru/yMnOx/γ-Al2O3-z catalyst. Table S1 showed the results of benzyl alcohol oxidation over Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Ru loading. When Ru loading was less than ca. 2.5 wt%, the initial conversion rate and the selectivity of benzaldehyde kept basically unchanged. However, when Ru loading was higher than ca. 2.5 wt%, the initial conversion rate dropped sharply. In order to obtain highly dispersed Ru species for the reaction, the Ru loading in each sample was fixed at a relatively low level of ∼ 2.5 wt%. Preparation of Ru(OH)x: An aqueous solution of RuCl3 (4.8 mmol/L) was slowly adjusted to pH of 13.0 by dripping a NaOH solution (1 mol/L) under continuous agitation, and the resulting slurry was further stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The solid was filtered, washed with deionized water until a neutral pH, and then dried at 80 °C for 6 h to obtain Ru (OH)x. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The characterization methods and specific experimental operations were described in the supporting information (SI). 2.4 Reactivity measurements Reactivity measurements were carried out using a bath-type reactor equipped with a reflux condenser and a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 1 mmol of benzyl alcohol (>99 %, Sinopharm) and 5 mL of toluene (as the reaction solvent, >99 %, Sinopharm,) were loaded into a 50 mL three-necked flask, and then a certain amount of catalyst was added to the mixture. The reaction was started by bubbling O2 into the mixture and the reaction temperature was controlled with an oil bath. After reaction, the solid catalyst was centrifuged and the liquid products were analyzed by an Agilent GC-7890 gas chromatograph equipped with a FID detector and a Rtx®-5 (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) capillary column. The carbon mass balance (C-balance) in each reaction was close to 100%. The benzyl alcohol conversion, aldehyde selectivity, and turnover frequency (TOF) were calculated by the following formula: (1) Conversion % = initial mol % − final mol % initial mol % × 100 % (2) Selectivity % = GC peak area of aldehyde GC peak area of all products × 100 % (3) TOF h − 1 = number of moles of aldedyde formed number of moles of Ru in the catalyst × reaction time 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of manganese content As shown in Fig. 2 (A), γ-Al2O3 carrier exhibited the IUPAC defined type IV isotherm with a H2 hysteresis loop and the corresponding BJH pore size distribution curve was shown in the illustration of Fig. 2 (A), indicating a typical mesoporous structure. The addition of Mn did not change the shape of the isotherm as well as the corresponding BJH pore size distribution curve, but the specific surface area and pore volume decreased slightly with increasing Mn loading (see Table 1), which might be attributed to a certain degree of pore blockage caused by the presence of MnOx species. Fig. 2(B) showed the XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 and yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples. Only broad diffraction peaks ascribed to γ-Al2O3 could be observed when the Mn loading was no more than ca. 10 wt%, indicating that the Mn species in these samples were highly dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3. However, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 18.2, 29.1, 32.7, 36.3, 38.4, 44.6, 51.2, 56.3, 58.8, 60.2 and 64.8° assigned to crystalline Mn3O4 (JCPDS 24–0734) could be discerned when the Mn loading was increased to ca. 20 wt%, implying large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 on the surface of this sample. Fig. 2(C) showed the FT-IR spectra of reference Mn3O4 and yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples. All Mn-containing samples exhibited two absorption bands around 3435 and 1643 cm−1, which were corresponding to the bending and stretching vibration of hydroxyl group or/and adsorbed water on the surface [41]. Crystalline Mn3O4 showed two intense absorption bands around 523 and 627 cm−1, which were associated with the stretching vibration of the octahedral and tetrahedral Mn-O bonds [42]. These two vibration absorption bands could also be detected in the 20 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 sample, indicating there were large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 in this special sample. It could be noticed that these two vibration absorption bands slightly shifted to higher frequencies, which might be associated with the formation of smaller particles of aggregated Mn3O4. However, no absorption bands attributed to Mn3O4 could be seen when the Mn loading was less than ca. 10 wt%. The result was consistent with the XRD characterization, further suggesting that the supported Mn species were highly dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3 at a low Mn loading level (≤ ca. 10 wt%). Raman spectroscopy has been proved as a useful technique for characterizing manganese oxide and supported manganese catalysts [43]. As shown in Fig. 2 (D), Mn3O4 reference spectrum exhibited a strong Raman peak at 658 cm−1 and two low-intensity peaks at 320 and 375 cm−1, which was in good agreement with literature [43,44]. Five major features at 361, 388, 529, 558 and 622 cm−1 could be recognized for MnO(OH) [44]. For yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 sample with a high Mn loading of ca. 20 wt%, one Raman shift at about 658 cm−1 attributed to Mn-O-Mn stretching vibrations of crystalline Mn3O4 could be detected clearly. The characteristic Raman bands of the Mn-O-Mn vibrations due to Mn3O4 could hardly be discerned for a low Mn loading sample, i.e., 5 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 and 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110. It could also be noted that there were two very broad vibration peaks between 350 and 700 cm−1 for these low Mn loading samples, which might be associated with highly dispersed Mn species on the support [43]. To further identify the Mn species supported on γ-Al2O3, XAS analysis was performed on the X-ray demonstration and development beam line of the Singapore Synchrontron Light Source (SSLS). As shown in Fig. S2, yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples as well as reference manganese oxides exhibited well-defined XANES characteristics with a small pre-edge peak attributed to the 1 s→3d transition. The Mn K-edge positions taken as the maximum peak of the first derivative for the K-edge XANES spectrum of yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples are listed in Table S2. A linear regression function is used to fit the Mn K-edge positions of reference manganese oxides with their oxidation states and the average oxidation states of yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples can be determined from its Mn K-edge position [45] (see Fig. 2 (F)). As shown in Table S2, the average oxidation states of Mn in 5 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 and 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 are 3.14 and 3.09, respectively, indicating that the Mn in these samples mainly exists as the Mn3+ ion. However, the average oxidation state of Mn in the 20 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 is 2.87, implying the coexistence of Mn2+ and Mn3+ in this special sample. According to literature reports, unstable Mn(OH)2 precipitates can be formed first when Mn2+ ions are hydrolyzed in an alkaline solution, and then the part can be gradually oxidized in air to form MnO(OH) precipitates [46]. Therefore, a mixture of Mn(OH)2 and MnO(OH) can be obtained when the Mn2+ ions are hydrolyzed in an alkaline solution under air. The aggregated Mn3O4 can be formed by dehydration of the mixture during aging [47]. Davies and coworkers [46] indicated that the presence of γ-Al2O3 could enhance the oxidation of Mn2+ in air when the solution pH was higher than 8.5. Therefore, it can be suggested that the Mn species supported on the surface of γ-Al2O3 are the coexistance of Mn3O4 and MnO(OH). As discussed above, the Mn species supported on γ-Al2O3 mainly existed as highly dispersed MnO(OH) when the Mn loading was no more than ca. 10 wt%, while a high Mn loading of ca. 20 wt% might lead to large amount of aggregated Mn3O4. Diffuse reflectance UV-Vis can provide information regarding the oxidation state of manganese and its chemical environment [48,49]. Fig. 2 (E) presented the UV–visible absorption spectra obtained for the yMnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples as well as Mn3O4 and MnO(OH). No band appeared for γ-Al2O3 in the range of 250–800 nm. Mn3O4 showed an absorption band in the 250–600 nm range. The charge transfer continuous bands reported at around 240–305 nm were assigned to O2-→Mn2+ and O2-→Mn3+ transitions, respectively [49], whereas the absorption band around 400 nm and 500 nm were attributed to the 6A1 g→4A1 g and 6A1 g→4T2 g crystal field transitions [48]. For MnO(OH), two bands around 300 and 400 nm were observed. The band at around 300 nm could be assigned to the O2-→Mn3+ transitions, and the band at around 400 nm might be assigned to the O2-→Mn3+ charge transfer transition superimposed with the 5B1 g→5B2 g and 5B1 g→5Eg crystal field d-d transitions [49]. The spectra of the yMnOx/γ-Al2O3 samples with a Mn loading less than ca. 10 wt% were very similar with that of MnO(OH), indicating the Mn species in these samples were close to MnO(OH). With the increase of Mn loading, the intensity of the absorption bands around 300 and 400 nm decreased. Meanwhile, the absorption around 300 nm shifted to lower wavelengths. These results might indicate a decrease of the proportion of Mn3+ in the yMnOx/γ-Al2O3 - 110 with the increase of Mn loading. This gave further support to our previous conclusions based on XRD, FT-IR, Raman, and XANES data. As can be seen from Fig. 3 (A)-(D), all samples show blocky-like structures with varied sizes, indicating that the influence of Mn loading on the morphology of the carrier was not significant. In addition, it could be observed that the surface of the Mn-free sample was relatively smooth, only with fewer small particle attached. With the increase of Mn loading, more particles adhered to the surface. When the content of manganese was less than ca. 10 wt%, the adhered particles were smaller and more uniform. When the Mn loading increased to ca. 20 wt%, the adhered particles aggregated into larger clusters.This was consistent with the results of XRD and FT-IR. According to DLS particle size analysis in toluene ( as shown in Fig. 3 (E)), the average particle size of Ru/γ-Al2O3 was about 1.2 micron. After the addition of Mn, the average particle size of the sample decreased significantly. With increasing Mn loading, the particle size distribution moved to a smaller particle size. However, when the Mn loading was higher than ca. 10 wt%, the particle size distribution did not change significantly with the Mn loading. Fig. S3 compared the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of Ru/γ-Al2O3 and Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 samples with different Mn loading. All samples displayed the type-IV isotherm. Compared with Ru/γ-Al2O3, the pore size of Mn-containing samples became slightly smaller, and their specific surface area and pore volume also decreased slightly (see Table 1), whereas the difference between the Ru/γ-MnOx/Al2O3–110 samples with different Mn loading was not obvious. Fig. S4 shows the XRD patterns of Ru/γ-Al2O3 and Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 –110. Except for the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3, no diffraction peaks attributed to Ru species could be detected in these samples, suggesting that the supported Ru species were highly dispersed or existed as the form of small nanoparticles. To clarify the ruthenium species on the carrier, ruthenium hydroxide prepared by treating an aqueous solution of RuCl3 (4.8 mmol/L) with a NaOH solution (1 mol/L) was characterized. The XPS spectra of Ru(OH)x (Fig. S5 (A)) showed that the binding energies of Ru 3p 3/2 and Ru 3p 1/2 were 463.0 and 485.0 eV, respectively, indicating that the average oxidation state of Ru was + 4. The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. S5 (B)) could be decomposed into three components, which were attributed to Ru-O-Ru oxygen atoms (33 %), Ru-OH oxygen atoms (55 %), and water (12 %). The results showed that the ratio of Ru-O-Ru oxygen atoms to Ru-OH oxygen atoms in Ru(OH)x was about 3:5. As can be seen from Fig. 4 (a)-(b), Ru nanoparticles are well dispersed on the carriers, but no lattice fringes can be observed, which hindering the exact identification of the supported Ru species as RuO2 or/and Ru(OH)4. The particle size of Ru in Ru/γ-Al2O3 is ranged from 1.2 to 4.5 nm with the average size of 2.3 nm. As for Ru/10 % MnOx/γ-Al2O3 –110, the particle size of Ru is in the range of 0.8–3.0 nm with the average size of 1.6 nm. Obviously, the addition of Mn can slightly decrease the size of supported Ru. The particle size distribution of the catalyst was further performed by HAADF-STEM characterization, and the nanoparticles were observed to be uniformly dispersed, shown in Fig. 4 (c). The EDX analysis was also performed to examine whether the active components distribution. The corresponding elemental mapping in a particular region of STEM image was obtained in the HADDF detection mode, shown in Fig. 4 (d)-(g). The element mapping results confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Ru and Mn species as well as their close contact. It is possible that the addition of Mn could enhance the interaction with the Ru precursors, thus improving the dispersion of supported Ru. The result suggested that there was a strong interaction between supported manganese and ruthenium, which might be the main reason for the slight reduction of the size of supported ruthenium. The chemical states of supported Ru were investigated by XPS. Since the Ru 3d peaks are partially overlapped with that of the C 1 s, the Ru 3p signal is used to study the changes in the Ru chemical state. As shown in Fig. 5 (A), the Ru 3p3/2 binding energy of all samples is centered at about 463.0 eV, which is consistent with that of ruthenium oxide (a possible hydrate species) [50], suggesting that the supported Ru in all samples exist as the form of + 4 valence. The Mn 2p3/2 spectra of all samples are very broad and asymmetical, indicating the coexistence of different valence states of manganese species.We conducted the peak deconvolution according to the literature [51], and three characteristic peaks at 640.5, 641.7 and 643.0 eV were corresponding to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively. As shown in Table 2 , The x/γ-Al2O3–110 contains mainly Mn3+ on the surface (64 %) along with 24 % of Mn2+ and 12 % of Mn4+. This is consistent with the results of XAS, reconfirming that the Mn species in this sample exist mainly in the form of MnO(OH). When the Mn loading increased to ca. 20 wt%, the Mn3+ content decreased to 21 %, while Mn2+ and Mn4+ increased to 53 % and 26 %, respectively. Because Mn3O4 can be considered a stoichiometric oxide of 2MnO·MnO2 [52], the proportional increase in Mn2+ and Mn4+ species suggests the formation of Mn3O4. This is basically consistent with the results of XRD, FT-IR, Raman and XAS. The O 1s specta can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 529.5 eV (α peak), 531.0 eV (β peak) and 533.0 eV (γ peak), corresponding to lattice oxygen (Osat), surface adsorbed oxygen (Ounsat) and surface adsorbed water, respectively [53]. As shown in Table 2, for the sample with a Mn loading of ca. 10 wt%, the ratio of Ounsat/(Ounsat+Osat) is 0.83, but when the Mn loading increased to ca. 20 wt%, the ratio decreased to 0.62. The result indicates that the sample with a Mn loading of ca. 10 wt% possessed more surface adsorbed oxygen species. More surface adsorbed oxygen species might promote the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Table 3 summarizes the catalytic activity of Ru/yMnOx/γ-Al2O3-z catalysts for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen. Pure γ-Al2O3 is almost inactive and Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst only gives a benzyl alcohol conversion of ca. 23 % with benzaldehyde selectivity of ca. 99 %. The addition of Mn can significantly improve the catalytic activity of Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, while the selectivity of benzaldehyde remains unchanged (see Fig. S6). The conversion of benzyl alcohol shows a growing tendency with Mn loading, and the highest benzyl alcohol conversion can be achieved with a Mn loading of ca. 10 wt%. Up to ca. 99 % of benzyl alcohol is converted to benzaldehyde at 60 °C within 3 h. By comparison, the 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 with the same Mn loading as Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 is tested for the benzyl alcohol oxidation, but only ca. 6 % of the benzyl alcohol conversion can be obtained. Therefore, the addition of Mn can significantly enhance the catalytic activity of Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the benzyl alcohol oxidation due to the synergistic effect between Ru and Mn cations. Such a phenomenon can also be seen over Ru/MnOx/CeO2 [41] and RuMnCe [42]. However, we also note that a further increase of the Mn loading obviously decreases the catalytic activity. Characterizations of XRD, FI-IR, UV-Vis, XPS and XAS suggested that the Mn species supported on γ-Al2O3 mainly exist as the highly dispersed MnO(OH) when the Mn loading is below ca. 10 wt%, while a large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 species are formed when excessive Mn (≥ ca. 20 wt%) is used. High dispersed MnO(OH) on γ-Al2O3 contains abundant surface reactive oxygen species, and there is strong interaction with supported ruthenium, thus resulting in significantly increased catalytic activity. Therefore, highly dispersed MnO(OH) can be suggested as the highly efficient promoter for supported Ru catalyst. It could be seen from Table 1 that the contents of Ru and Mn determined by XPS were much higher than that of ICP, which indicated that Ru and Mn species were enriched on the surface of the catalyst, which might be another reason for the high catalytic activity of the supported Ru catalyst. 3.2 Effect of calcination temperature The N2 adsorption isotherms and the corresponding BJH pore size distribution curve of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 samples roasted at different temperature are shown in Fig. 6 (A)-(B). All samples exhibit the type IV isotherms with a H2 hysteresis in the range of relative pressure 0.35–0.85 and the pore size distributions are concentrated at 3–5 nm, indicating a typical mesoporous structure. It can be seen from Table 1 that the pore sizes of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 roasted at different temperature are concentrated at about 3.4–3.8 nm, indicating that the roasting temperature has little affect the pore size of the sample. We also noticed that the specific area and pore volume of the sample increased slightly after a high temperature roasting, which might be caused by the overflow of crystal water or the decomposition of supported MnOx. Fig. 6(C) shows the XRD patterns of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 samples roasted at different temperatures. Only diffraction peaks ascribed to γ-Al2O3 can be detected when the roasting temperature is below 300 °C, indicating that the supported Mn species are highly dispersed on γ-Al2O3. As discussed in the previous section, the supported Mn species are highly dispersed MnO(OH). However, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.7, 36.3 and 60.2° attributed to Mn3O4 can be detected when a roasting temperature of 500 °C is used, indicating the presence of large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 in the sample, which may be formed by the decomposition of supported MnO(OH) species at a high temperature. Fig. 6(D) exhibits the H2-TPR profiles of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 samples roasted at different temperature. The H2-TPR curves of the samples roasted at 110 and 300 °C are very similar, and both show two consecutive reduction peaks in the temperature range from 150 to 550 °C, which is corresponding to the successive reduction of MnOx (MnO(OH))→Mn3O4→MnO [54]. We also note that the location and area ratio of these two reduction peaks in both samples are very close, indicating that the supported Mn species might have the similar form. The first reduction peak of the sample roasted at 500 °C is significantly decreased, indicating that the oxidation state of the supported Mn is obviously reduced, which is consistent with the XRD results, and further proves that the supported Mn species is partly decomposed at high temperature and large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 species are formed. Fig. 7(A) shows the Ru 3p 3/2 XPS of Ru/10 %MnOx/Al2O3 samples roasted at different temperature. According to the binding energy of Ru 3p 3/2, it can be inferred that the Ru in these samples exists in the form of + 4 valence, indicating that the roasting temperature of 10 %MnOx/Al2O3 almost has no effect upon the oxidation state of supported Ru. As can be seen from Fig. 7 (B) and Table 2, the Mn in the sample roasted at 110 °C is mainly in the form of Mn3+, while the Mn in the sample roasted at 500 °C is mainly in the form of Mn2+. Considering that Mn3O4 can be regarded as a stoichiometric oxide of 2MnO·MnO2, it is reasonable to suggest that there are a large amount of Mn3O4 species in the sample roasted at 500 °C, which is basically consistent with the results of XRD and TPR. The O 1s spectra (Fig. 7 (C)) and Table 2 suggested that the low-temperature sample contained more surface adsorbed oxygen species, while the high-temperature sample significantly reduced the amount of surface adsorbed oxygen species. As can be seen in Table 3, the catalytic activity of Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3-z gradually decreases with the roasting temperature, and it decreases sharply as the roasting temperature is higher than 500 °C. Among them, the Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 -110 shows the highest catalytic activity. According the characterizations, the Mn species in the sample roasted at 110 °C mainly exist as highly dispersed MnO(OH), and these MnO(OH) species can gradually decompose and aggregate to Mn3O4 with an increase of the roasting temperature, and large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 can be formed in the sample roasted at 500 °C. In addition, we note that the roasting temperature only has a little effect on the specific area and pore volume of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 samples. Therefore，it can be suggested that the poor promotion effect of aggregated Mn3O4 is an important reason for the decreased catalytic activity of high-temperature roasted catalyst. 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions As mentioned above, the Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity among the catalysts investigated. Subsequently, the reaction condition optimization was performed on this catalyst. First, we investigated the influence of the reaction solvent. As can be seen in Table 4, the non-polar and aprotic toluene is particularly efficient for the conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Although a high benzyl alcohol conversion can be obtained when dichloroethane is used as the solvent, the selectivity of benzaldehyde is relatively low. Using acetonitrile, tetrahydrofuran or N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF) as the solvent, a high selectivity of benzaldehyde can be achieved, but the conversion of benzyl alcohol is poor. As for other solvents such as ethyl acetate, the benzyl alcohol conversion rate as well as the selectivity of benzaldehyde are low. In general, the non-polar solvent is beneficial to the conversion of benzyl alcohol and the formation of benzaldehyde. Subsequently, we investigated the effect of the reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. 8 (A), when the reaction temperature is 30–80 °C, the selectivity of benzaldehyde is ca. 100 % and the conversion of benzyl alcohol increases with increasing temperature. After 24 h reaction at 30 °C, the conversion of benzyl alcohol is only ca. 88 %. After 3 h reaction at 60 °C, the benzyl conversion is over ca. 99 %. When the reaction temperature is raised to 80 °C, the conversion of benzyl alcohol is close to complete within 1 h. Fig. 8 (B) shows the effect of the amount of catalyst on the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. When the amount of catalyst increased from 25 to 100 mg, the selectivity of benzaldehyde remained unchanged, while the conversion of benzyl alcohol increased with increasing the amount of catalyst. It is worth noting that this growth trend slows down when the amount of catalyst is exceeded 50 mg.The effect of reaction time on the oxidation of benzyl alcohol was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 8 (C), the selectivity of benzaldehyde remained unchanged, while the conversion of benzyl alcohol increased with reaction time. We noticed that in the initial stage of the reaction, the conversion of benzyl alcohol increased rapidly with time, and more than ca. 80 % of benzyl alcohol conversion could be achieved after 1 h of reaction, and then gradually slowed down. After 3 h of reaction, the conversion of benzyl alcohol could be completed. We also examined the effect of reaction atmosphere. When the reaction was conducted using air instead of O2, the selectivity of benzaldehyde remained unchanged, but the conversion of benzyl alcohol was reduced by about ca. 10 %. When pure N2 was introduced for the reaction, the benzyl alcohol conversion was only about ca. 9 %. It could be seen that the oxygen atmosphere played an important role in the conversion of benzyl alcohol and the formation of benzaldehyde. The catalytic activity of Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 –110 was compared with many Ru-based heterogeneous catalyst for aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol and it was described in Table 5. Although the reaction conditions are quite different, these results are still highly comparable in terms of catalyst productivity. The advantages of Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst compared with other reported catalysts are mainly (a) the low-level loading of Ru for the catalyst leading to a high TOF, (b) for achieving ca. 100 % conversion of benzyl alcohol, the needed reaction time is shorter and the reaction temperature is lower, (c) there are few by-products and the selectivity of aldehyde is more than ca. 99 %. The highest TOF value obtained in this work is 88 h−1, which is higher than the best TOF (69 h−1) reported in the literature. Although 9.2 %RuO/NaY catalyst shows a high TOF value (48 h−1) at a low reaction temperature of 70 °C, the conversion of benzyl alcohol is low. Moreover, the catalyst is also comparable to other precious metal catalysts reported in the literature, and molecular oxygen is used as the sole oxidant and no other additive is required during the reaction. In order to study the catalytic potential of Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst, more aerobic oxidation was carried out for a variety of alcohols as shown in Table 6. Various benzylic alcohols can be selectively converted into the corresponding aldehyde with excellent yield with 1.5–12 h reaction at 60 °C. Phenyl ethanol and cinnamyl alcohol are moderately reactive, and the corresponding carbonly compound are obtained in ca. 49–77 % yields for 12 h of reaction. Aliphatic alcohols such as cyclohexanol only gives a low yield (ca. 8 %) of product. In addition, some more other organic conversion reactions were attempted on Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst. The N-alkylation of anline with benzyl alcohol can be efficiently promoted by Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst under 1 atm of Ar ( Scheme 1), and ca. 99 % yield of imine can be achieved at 132 °C within 5 h. After reaction at 100 °C for 24 h, acetophenone can be reduced to the corresponding 1-phenylethanol with a yield of ca. 68 % using 2-propanol as a hydrogen donor ( Scheme 2). Furthermore, the present Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst is also active for the aerobic oxidation of benzylamine to the corresponding product, as show in ( Scheme 3). 3.4 Recyclability of the catalyst After reaction, the used Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst was recovered by contrifugation and washed with 0.1 M NaOH and deionized water, followed by drying overnight in an oven at 80 °C, the regenerated catalyst was used in the next run. As shown in Fig. 9 (A), the benzyl alcohol conversion and the benzaldehyde selectivity do not decrease significantly in the repeated runs. In order to verify whether there were any Ru and/or Mn species leaching during the reaction, the catalyst was removed by filtration after 0.5 h of reaction and the filtrate was kept to continue for two and a half hours under the same reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 9 (B), the reaction halted right away after the catalyst was removed. In addition, the liquid filtrate that the solid catalyst removed after reaction was analyzed by ICP. No Ru and Mn ions can be detected, indicating that the active components leaching from Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 during the reaction can be ignored and the oxidation reaction is carried out on the solid catalyst. The XRD patterns shown in Fig. S7 suggested that the spent catalyst also could maintain the characteristic crystal phase of the fresh catalyst. The comparison of Ru 3p XPS of the spent catalyst and the fresh catalyst (as shown in Fig. S8) showed that the intensity of spectral peak decreased slightly but the binding energy of Ru 3p 3/2 hardly shifted, indicating that the oxidation state of Ru remained almost constant before and after the reaction. These results clearly suggest that the Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst exhibits high stability and good recyclability for the reaction. In order to study the thermal stability of the Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst, the TG-DSC curves of the sample were determined on a Netzsch STA449C thermal analyzer. As show in Fig. S9, the sample has a significant weight loss between 100 and 300 °C, and the DSC curve also shows a strong exothermic peak near 110 °C, indicating that the active components in the sample may decompose at a temperature above 100 °C. Therefore, the temperature at which the catalyst stable should be below 100 °C. 3.5 Mechanistic considerations As shown in Table 3, the benzyl alcohol conversions of Ru/γ-Al2O3 and 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 are ca. 23 % and ca. 6 %, respectively. It means that the conversion rate of benzyl alcohol on Ru/γ-Al2O3 is about four times that of 10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110. Moreover, XPS results in Fig. S5 suggest that the supported Ru species exist in the form of Ru(OH)x. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the Ru(OH)x is the main active component of Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen, and the supported MnOx, especially highly dispersed MnO(OH), is the main promoter of the catalyst. In order to demonstrate the role of highly dispersed MnO(OH) during the reaction, EPR analysis of the fresh and spend Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst was performed. As shown in Fig. 10, both EPR spectra of the fresh and spend catalyst exhibit six hyperfine lines with a g value of about 2.0 and a hyperfine coupling constant (A value) around 91 G, indicating the existence of Mn2+ ions [59]. It also can be seen a considerable increase of the intensities of the resonance peaks for the spend catalyst as compared with the fresh catalyst, indicating an increase of Mn2+ proportion. The result means that part of the Mn3+ species are reduced to Mn2+ species during the reaction. Moreover, Fig. S8 showed that the oxidation state of Ru remained unchange before and after the reaction. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the conversion between Mn2+ ions and Mn3+ ions provides electrons for the activation of molecular oxygen. In order to verify whether the oxidation reaction involved a radical, 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol was added as a free radical trap during the reaction, and the conversion of benzyl alcohol and the selectivity of benzaldehyde were not changed. In addition, the mixed liquid extracted during the reaction was analyzed by EPR spectroscopy, but no obvious free radical signal could be detected. These results indicated that the oxidation reaction did not involve a free radical mechanism. As shown in Table 6, the oxidation of primary alcohols (Table 6 entry 1) was much faster than that of secondary alcohols (Table 6 entry 6), which might suggest the formation of Ru-alcoholate intermediate during the reaction, since the formation of metal-alcoholate species was well known to for the oxidation of primary hydroxyl groups [60]. As shown in (Scheme 2), acetophenone could be reduced to the corresponding 1-phenylethanol with using 2-propanol as a hydrogen donor under Ar, which might indicate that Ru-H species was formed during the reaction. According to the above results, the Ru-alcoholate species was the first intermediate formed by the reaction of Ru hydroxide species with the alcohol, and then the alcohol conducted the typical β elimination to form the corresponding carbonyl compound and Ru-H species. Ru-H species can be oxidized by molecular oxygen. It is generally accepted that the β-hydride elimination from a Ru alkoxide is the rate-determining step of the aerobic oxidation of alcohols over supported Ru catalyst [34]. The enhanced activity can be considered as the result of the interaction between supported MnOx and ruthenium [39]. The foregoing result has proved that the promoting effect of MnOx with different structures on ruthenium is quite different. Among them, highly dispersed MnO(OH) is a very efficient facilitator, which may be due to the special structure and properties of highly dispersed MnO(OH) [61]. In addition, supported MnOx is also known to be the highly effective active component to activate molecular oxygen [14], which can produce active oxygen species for oxidizing ruthenium hydride species obtained by the β-hydride elimination to ruthenium hydroxo species. Our previous studies have confirmed that highly dispersed MnO(OH) shows better ability to activate molecular oxygen than that of aggregated Mn3O4 [61], which may be another reason for the increased catalyst activity. As shown in Fig. 11, the oxidation mechanism of benzyl alcohol on Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3 -110 catalyst can be regarded as an oxidative dehydrogenation of a Ru(IV) alkoxide-based intermediate formed by the reaction of Ru(IV) hydroxo species with benzyl alcohol, such as Ru(IV)-OH + RCH2OH→Ru(IV)-OCH2R + H2O, followed by β-hydride elimination to obtain aldehyde and ruthenium hydride species. The latter are then oxidized by O2 to give Ru(IV) hydroxo species. During the reoxidation of catalyst, the supported MnO(OH) species play an important role in the activation of molecular oxygen. 4 Conclusion The effect of Mn loading on the structure and catalytic performances of Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 were studied. When the Mn loading is no more than ca. 10 wt%, the supported Mn exists in the form of highly dispersed MnO(OH), which can enhance the interaction with ruthenium precursor, increasing the dispersion of the supported Ru, thus significantly improving the catalytic activity of supported Ru catalyst. When the Mn loading is higher than ca. 20 wt%, a large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 will be formed, resulting in a decrease of the catalytic activity. Therefore, highly dispersed MnO(OH) is a highly efficient promoter for supported Ru catalyst. In addition, the effect of roasting temperature on the structure and catalytic performance of Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was also studied. The Mn in the sample roasted at 110 °C mainly existed in the form of highly dispersed MnO(OH). With a increase of roasting temperature, the supported MnO(OH) gradually aggregated to Mn3O4. Large amount of aggregated Mn3O4 species are presented in the sample roasted at 500 °C. The weak promotion of aggregated Mn3O4 is an important reason for the decreased catalytic activity of high-temperature roasted catalyst. The developed Ru/10 %MnOx/γ-Al2O3–110 catalyst showed the best activity for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The high yield of benzaldehyde of 99 % could be obtained at 80 °C with 1 h of reaction. Its TOF value was 88 h−1, which was much better than that reported in the literature. Moreover, the catalyst also exhibited high stability and good recyclability for the reaction. Supporting Information Supplementary data associated with this work can be found in the online version. coredata.dc:description: Ru/MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared by a facile sequential precipitation- deposition method were investigated for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol with molecular oxygen. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalyst were characterized by multiple analytical and characterization techniques. It was found that the highly dispersed MnO(OH) could significantly improve the catalyst activity. When a Mn loading of ca. 10 wt% was used, the catalytic activity of supported Ru catalyst was the highest. The benzyl alcohol conversion and the selectivity of benzaldehyde after 1 h reaction at 80 °C were 100 % and 99 %, respectively. Excessive Mn, however, would lead to large amount of aggregated Mn3O4, resulting in a poor activity. The Mn in the sample roasted below 300 °C was highly dispersed MnO(OH), and the corresponding catalyst showed a high activity. High-temperature aggregated MnO(OH) to Mn3O4, leading to a decreased catalyst activity.
